    [Leetcode] 190. Reverse Bits

    7 minute read

    H√¥m nay m√¨nh s·∫Ω m·ªü ƒë·∫ßu cho series gi·∫£i ƒë·ªÅ tr√™n leetcode ü•≥ V√¨ kh·∫£ nƒÉng c√≤n r·∫•t c√≥ h·∫°n n√™n m√¨nh s·∫Ω ch·ªçn nh·ªØng b√†i d·ªÖ l√†m tr∆∞·ªõc hehe.

    B√†i ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n l√† 190. Reverse Bits

    Reverse bits of a given 32 bits unsigned integer.

    Note:

    Note that in some languages such as Java, there is no unsigned integer type. In this case, both input and output will be given as a signed integer type. They should not affect your implementation, as the integer‚Äôs internal binary representation is the same, whether it is signed or unsigned.

    In Java, the compiler represents the signed integers using 2‚Äôs complement notation. Therefore, in Example 2 above, the input represents the signed integer -3 and the output represents the signed integer -1073741825.

    Follow up:

    If this function is called many times, how would you optimize it?

    Constraints:

    The input must be a binary string of length 32

    Example 1

    Input: n = 00000010100101000001111010011100
Output:    964176192 (00111001011110000010100101000000)
Explanation: The input binary string 00000010100101000001111010011100 represents the unsigned integer 43261596, so return 964176192 which its binary representation is 00111001011110000010100101000000.

    Example 2

    Input: n = 11111111111111111111111111111101
Output:   3221225471 (10111111111111111111111111111111)
Explanation: The input binary string 11111111111111111111111111111101 represents the unsigned integer 4294967293, so return 3221225471 which its binary representation is 10111111111111111111111111111111.

    Ph√¢n t√≠ch ƒë·ªÅ

    Theo ƒë·ªÅ b√†i y√™u c·∫ßu th√¨ m√¨nh c·∫ßn chuy·ªÉn m·ªôt s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n(c√≥ 32 bit), ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c n v√† chuy·ªÉn n√≥ v·ªÅ l·∫°i gi√° tr·ªã s·ªë nguy√™n t∆∞∆°ng ·ª©ng.

    Nh∆∞ trong v√≠ d·ª• 1, n c√≥ gi√° tr·ªã s·ªë nguy√™n l√† 43261596 v√† ·ªü d·∫°ng binary th√¨

    n = 00000010100101000001111010011100 th√¨ ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c c·ªßa

    n ·ªü d·∫°ng bit t·ª´ sau ra tr∆∞·ªõc l√†: 0011100101111000001010010100000

    Sau khi ƒë√£ c√≥ ƒë∆∞·ª£c s·ªë ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c, th√¨ k·∫øt qu·∫£ ch√≠nh l√† s·ªë ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c ƒë√≥ ·ªü d·∫°ng s·ªë nguy√™n, l√† 3221225471

    V√† k·∫øt qu·∫£ ƒë√∫ng ch√≠nh l√† 3221225471

    ƒê·ªÉ gi·∫£i ƒë∆∞·ª£c b√†i n√†y, m√¨nh c·∫ßn bi·∫øt:

    ‚Äì c√°ch chuy·ªÉn m·ªôt s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ m·ªôt s·ªë d·∫°ng bit v√† ng∆∞·ª£c l·∫°i, chuy·ªÉn m·ªôt s·ªë d·∫°ng bit v·ªÅ m·ªôt s·ªë nguy√™n, v√≠ d·ª•:

    ‚Äì chuy·ªÉn v·ªÅ binary: 12 = 8 + 4 = 1* 2^3 + 1 * 2^2 + 0 * 2^1 + 0 * 2^0 = 110

    ‚Äì chuy·ªÉn v·ªÅ s·ªë nguy√™n: 1010 = 1 * 2^3 + 0 * 2^2 + 1 * 2^1 + 0 * 2^0 = 8 + 0 + 2 + 0 = 10

    ‚Äì c√°ch ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt chu·ªói, v√≠ d·ª• ‚Äò1010‚Äò th√†nh ‚Äò0101‚Äô.

    H∆∞·ªõng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n 1:

    Chuy·ªÉn s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë binary v√† ng∆∞·ª£c l·∫°i

    Chuy·ªÉn s·ªë binary v·ªÅ s·ªë nguy√™n b·∫±ng c√°ch chia cho 2

    ·ªû c√°ch n√†y, m√¨nh l·∫ßn l∆∞·ª£t chia s·ªë ƒë√≥ cho 2 v√† nh·∫≠n ƒë∆∞·ª£c k·∫øt qu·∫£ l√† x v√† s·ªë d∆∞ l√† 0 n·∫øu chia h·∫øt cho 2, ho·∫∑c 1 n·∫øu chia kh√¥ng h·∫øt cho hai. Ti·∫øp t·ª•c l·∫•y x chia v·ªõi 2 cho ƒë·∫øn khi nh·∫≠n k·∫øt qu·∫£ cu·ªëi c√πng l√† 0. Khi ƒë√≥, s·ªë binary s·∫Ω ƒë∆∞·ª£c l·∫•y theo th·ª© t·ª± t·ª´ d∆∞·ªõi l√™n tr√™n.

    C√°ch l√†m n√†y ƒë∆∞·ª£c m√¥ t·∫£ nh∆∞ sau:

    Trong code s·∫Ω m√¥ t·∫£ l√†:

    def number_to_binary(n):
    if n >= 1:
        number_to_binary(n // 2)
        print(n % 2, end=" ")

    Code m√¥ t·∫£ cho c√¥ng vi·ªác n√†y m√¨nh c√≥ l√†m ·ªü ƒë√¢y, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ fork v·ªÅ t√†i kho·∫£n c·ªßa m√¨nh ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c h√†nh nh√©.

    Chuy·ªÉn s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë binary b·∫±ng c√°ch nh√¢n cho 2

    Ng∆∞·ª£c l·∫°i, ƒë·ªÉ chuy·ªÉn t·ª´ s·ªë binary v·ªÅ s·ªë nguy√™n m√¨nh c·∫ßn th·ª±c hi·ªán nh√¢n cho 2 v√† c·ªông d·ªìn k·∫øt qu·∫£ v·ªõi c√°c s·ªë d∆∞, ch√≠nh l√† c√°c s·ªë binary 0 hay 1.

    Nh∆∞ m√¥ t·∫£ tr√™n h√¨nh, th√¨ m√¨nh s·∫Ω l·∫∑p qua t·ª´ng s·ªë trong s·ªë binary, r·ªìi th·ª±c hi·ªán nh√¢n k·∫øt qu·∫£ ƒëang c√≥ cho 2 v√† c·ªông v·ªõi s·ªë d∆∞ ch√≠nh l√† s·ªë binary ·ªü th·ªùi ƒëi·ªÉm hi·ªán t·∫°i.

    B·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu v·ªõi gi√° tr·ªã 0, s·ªë ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n l√† 1 n√™n k·∫øt qu·∫£ c√≥ ƒë∆∞·ª£c l√† 0 * 2 + 1 = 1

    Ti·∫øp theo, b·∫Øt ƒë·∫ßu v·ªõi 1, s·ªë ti·∫øp theo l√† 1 n√™n k·∫øt qu·∫£ c√≥ ƒë∆∞·ª£c l√† 1 * 2 + 1 = 3

    V√† ti·∫øp t·ª•c th·ª±c hi·ªán cho ƒë·∫øn h·∫øt.

    Code m√¥ t·∫£ cho c√¥ng vi·ªác n√†y m√¨nh c√≥ l√†m ·ªü ƒë√¢y, b·∫°n c√≥ th·ªÉ fork v·ªÅ t√†i kho·∫£n c·ªßa m√¨nh ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c h√†nh nh√©.

    def binary_to_number(b):
  n = 0
  for digit in b:
    n = n * 2 + int(digit)

  return n

    Gi·∫£i b√†i to√°n v·ªõi h∆∞·ªõng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n 1

    V·∫≠y l√† ƒë√£ r√µ c√°ch chuy·ªÉn gi·ªØa s·ªë nguy√™n v√† s·ªë binary r·ªìi, c√≤n vi·ªác ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c m·ªôt chu·ªói th√¨ ƒë∆°n gi·∫£n l√† m√¨nh s·ª≠ d·ª•ng slice trong Python [::-1]

    M√¨nh c√≥ th·ªÉ b·∫Øt tay v√†o gi·∫£i b√†i n√†y r·ªìi ƒë√≥, b·∫°n n√£y l√†m th·ª≠ ·ªü t√†i kho·∫£n leetcode c·ªßa m√¨nh tr∆∞·ªõc khi xem ƒë√°p √°n nha.

    M·ªôt g·ª£i √Ω nh·ªè n·ªØa l√† ƒë·ªÅ b√†i y√™u c·∫ßu s·ªë binary c·ªßa m√¨nh c√≥ 32 bit, n√™n sau khi chuy·ªÉn t·ª´ s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n r·ªìi, n·∫øu ch∆∞a ƒë·ªß 32 bit th√¨ m√¨nh c·∫ßn th√™m s·ªë 0 ·ªü ph√≠a tr∆∞·ªõc k·∫øt qu·∫£ cho ƒë·ªß 32 bit tr∆∞·ªõc khi th·ª±c hi·ªán ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c th·ª© t·ª± nh√©.

    Code Python
    class Solution:
    def reverseBits(self, n: int) -> int:
        n_binary_str = ""
        n_binary_str = self.number_to_binary(n, n_binary_str)
        
        # because n in binary could not enough 32 bit then need to fill 0 until reach 32 bit
        while len(n_binary_str) < 32:
            n_binary_str = "0" + n_binary_str
        
        # reverse the order of the binary
        n_binary_str = n_binary_str[::-1]
        
        # convert back to integer with binary
        x = int(n_binary_str, 2)
        return x
        
        
    def number_to_binary(self, n, n_binary_str):
        if n >= 1:
            n_binary_str = str(n % 2) + n_binary_str
            return self.number_to_binary(n // 2, n_binary_str)
        
        return n_binary_str

    
    def binary_to_number(self, binary, n):
        if n >= 1:
            n_binary_str = str(n % 2) + n_binary_str
            return self.number_to_binary(n // 2, n_binary_str)
        
        return n_binary_s

    Tuy nhi√™n, tuy nhi√™n, k·∫øt qu·∫£ n√†y d√π ƒë√∫ng nh∆∞ng v·∫´n ch·∫≠m l·∫Øm, khi m√¨nh submit b√†i t·∫≠p ch·ªâ h∆°n c√≥ 7% nh·ªØng ng∆∞·ªùi kh√°c th√¥i. Cho n√™n ti·∫øp theo m√¨nh s·∫Ω c√πng ƒëi th√™m m·ªôt h∆∞·ªõng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n kh√°c hay ho h∆°n nha, hi v·ªçng s·∫Ω nhanh h∆°n n√†o.

    H∆∞·ªõng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n 2:

    Th·ª±c ra, ngay t·ª´ ƒë·∫ßu m√¨nh c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒëi theo h∆∞·ªõng n√†y li·ªÅn, cho n√≥ nhanh g·ªçn, nh∆∞ng m√† m√¨nh mu·ªën m√¨nh v√† c√°c b·∫°n ƒë·ªçc b√†i vi·∫øt n√†y c√≥ th·ªÉ hi·ªÉu th√™m v·ªÅ c√°ch chuy·ªÉn ƒë·ªïi gi·ªØa s·ªë nguy√™n v√† s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n n√™n m√¨nh m·ªõi ƒëi theo h∆∞·ªõng kia tr∆∞·ªõc. V·ªõi h∆∞·ªõng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n 1 th√¨ d√π b·∫°n c√≥ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng ng√¥n ng·ªØ n√†o ƒë·ªÉ th·ª±c hi·ªán b√†i to√°n th√¨ ƒë·ªÅu c√≥ th·ªÉ √°p d·ª•ng ƒë∆∞·ª£c.

    Chuy·ªÉn s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë binary v√† ng∆∞·ª£c l·∫°i

    Trong Python, c√≥ m·ªôt h√†m built-in c√≥ th·ªÉ gi√∫p m√¨nh chuy·ªÉn s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n t√™n l√† bin

    >>> bin(12)
'0b1100'
>>> bin(12).replace("0b", "")
'1100'

    Ngo√†i ra, c√≤n m·ªôt c√°ch kh√°c n·ªØa c√≥ th·ªÉ chuy·ªÉn t·ª´ s·ªë nguy√™n sang s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n ·ªü d·∫°ng chu·ªói b·∫±ng c√°ch d√πng h√†m format v·ªõi d·∫°ng binary, n√≥ s·∫Ω nh∆∞ th·∫ø n√†y

    >>> "{0:b}".format(int(12))
'1100'

    V√† ƒë·ªÉ chuy·ªÉn ng∆∞·ª£c t·ª´ s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n sang s·ªë nguy√™n m√¨nh c√≥ th·ªÉ s·ª≠ d·ª•ng h√†m int c√≥ s·∫µn trong Python v·ªõi base l√† 2. H√†m n√†y m·∫∑c ƒë·ªãnh c√≥ base l√† 10.

    >>> int('1100', 2)

>>> int('1100', base=2)

    Gi·∫£i b√†i to√°n v·ªõi h∆∞·ªõng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n 2

    H·∫≥n l√† b·∫°n ƒë√£ th·∫•y c√°ch n√†y n√≥ ƒë∆°n gi·∫£n nh∆∞ th·∫ø n√†o r·ªìi, v√† b√†i gi·∫£i c·ªßa m√¨nh ch·ªâ ƒë∆°n gi·∫£n l√† nh∆∞ th·∫ø n√†y:

    class Solution:
    def reverseBits(self, n: int) -> int:
        # chuy·ªÉn s·ªë nguy√™n v·ªÅ s·ªë nh·ªã ph√¢n
        n_binary_str = bin(n).replace("0b", "")
        
        # th√™m s·ªë 0 cho ƒë·ªß 32 bit
        while len(n_binary_str) < 32:
            n_binary_str = "0" + n_binary_str
        
        # ƒë·∫£o ng∆∞·ª£c th·ª© t·ª± 
        n_binary_str = n_binary_str[::-1]
        
        # chuy·ªÉn nh·ªã ph√¢n v·ªÅ s·ªë nguy√™n
        return int(n_binary_str, 2)

    V√† t√©n ten, l·∫ßn submit n√†y ƒë√£ h∆°n 88.74% nh·ªØng submissions kh√°c r·ªìi ü•∞

    B·∫£n t·ªëi ∆∞u t·ª´ m·ªôt b·∫°n comment b√™n Kipalog

    Sau khi m√¨nh ƒëƒÉng b√†i vi·∫øt tr√™n Kipalog th√¨ c√≥ m·ªôt b·∫°n comment kh√° hay n√™n m√¨nh l∆∞u l·∫°i c√°ch gi·∫£i n√†y ƒë·ªÉ tham kh·∫£o, m·ªôt v√†i ƒëi·ªÉm hay ·ªü ƒë√°p √°n n√†y l√†:

    ‚Äì ch·ªâ d√πng m·ªôt d√≤ng code

    ‚Äì d√πng h√†m zfill trong Python ƒë·ªÉ ƒëi·ªÅn s·ªë 0 ph√≠a tr∆∞·ªõc cho ƒë·ªß 32 bit

    class Solution:
    def reverseBits(self, n: int) -> int:
        return int(bin(n)[2:].zfill(32)[::-1], 2)
